awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Exchange, Craft Specialization And The Development Of Social Complexity
awd_abstract_narration:
The central goal of this research is to understand how complex social entities such as states develop. What are the links which serve in "traditional" societies to join large groups of individuals spread over thousands of square miles into effectively functioning social units? To what extent are economic factors central and where in the social structure do the driving forces arise? Archaeology can effectively address this issue since it can trace developmental trajectories often over millennial time spans. 

With support from the National Science Foundation, Drs. Deborah L. Nichols and Wesley D. Stoner will investigate the development of craft specialization and exchange in the formation of early complex societies, a central research directive for archaeology. Central Mexico is a key region to study these developments as the heartland for the development of a series of large and influential early states and cities. Nichols and Stoner and a team of collaborators from the U.S. and Mexico will survey and excavate at the site of Altica, one of the earliest farming settlements and obsidian-working sites in the Teotihuacan Valley, Mexico, that dates to the Early and Middle Formative (ca. 1300-850 BC). Altica is one of the best-preserved of the first farming villages in the Basin of Mexico. It is also one of the only known early villages in the northern Basin that worked obsidian from the Otumba source that, with the development of blade making, became widely exchanged in Mesoamerica. Altica thus became an active node within broad-scale interaction networks that connected the Teotihuacan Valley to other parts of Mesoamerica. Intensification and expansion of these early networks formed the social and economic foundation that propelled subsequent Basin polities to prominence in Mesoamerica.

Archaeological survey and excavations at Altica aim to reconstruct the site's role in establishing these early political and economic networks. The team will survey the ridge on which Altica is located and intensively survey and map the site itself and make systematic collections of surface artifacts. Based on the survey and limited geophysical prospection, excavations will focus on areas with artifact concentrations of possible subsurface features to obtain representative samples of artifacts in context. These data will help address to key questions: did emerging elites and the political economy prompt craft specialization or did its origins lie in the household economy of early farmers?  Fieldwork at Altica will contribute new knowledge about early village life, agricultural landuse, and the development of specialized obsidian tool manufacturing and exchange systems. To understand Altica's role in the organization of early trading networks and craft specialization, the researchers will analyze artifacts from key collections of other Early and Middle Formative sites in the Basin of Mexico and apply a multi-technique approach to compositional analyses of ceramics and obsidian from the larger Central Mexico macro-region.
	 
The broader impact of this project is to renew research on the Formative period in the Basin of Mexico that spanned the founding of the first villages to the development of the first cities and states. This project is an important step in addressing the near lack of problem-oriented research at Formative sites in the Basin of Mexico over the past quarter century. The project will provide training and research for younger archaeologists and students who in recent decades have had limited opportunities for research at Formative sites in the Basin of Mexico. The project involves substantial collaboration with archaeologists and students from Mexico and the US and will contribute to international scientific cooperation.

Collaborative Research: Craft Specialization, Exchange, and the Development of Early Complex Societies in Central Mexico

 Project Outcomes

 With support from the National Science Foundation, Drs. Deborah L. Nichols and Wesley D. Stoner have investigated how craft specialization and exchange contributed to the development of early complex societies, a central research directive for archaeology. Central Mexico is a key region to study these developments as the heartland for the growth of a series of large and influential early states and cities. In 2014 Nichols and Stoner and a team of collaborators from the U.S. and Mexico surveyed and excavated at the site of Altica in the Teotihuacan Valley, northeast of Mexico City. Their investigations demonstrate that Altica is the earliest-known settled village in the Teotihuacan Valley and one of the only first-farming village sites in the Basin of Mexico that has not been engulfed by the urban sprawl of Mexico City. Altica initiated a long history of continuous occupation leading to the founding of Teotihuacan that in the first century A.D. became the most influential city in Mesoamerica.

Altica has been heavily eroded and disturbed by modern land use. Surface collections of artifacts and a geophysical survey with a magnetometer guided the placement of excavation. As Nichols and Stoner anticipated, erosion had removed remains of Formative-period houses but excavations found 25 ancient features and recovered thousands of artifacts. Radiocarbon dates from the Altica excavations provide the earliest dates both for the cultivation of crops, including maize, and the initial use of ceramics in the Teotihuacan Valley. Altica was occupied for about 350 years from 1150 to 850 cal. BC. The excavated features at Altica included pits dug into bedrock. Four contained human burials that are the earliest from any village in the Teotihuacan Valley.

The evidence from Altica confirms larger trends across Mesoamerica at this time for increased reliance on agriculture. Botanical analyses confirm the presence of maize and many other crops, including amaranth, chenopodium, sunflower, chile, and lowland tubers that were likely imported. The project recovered the earliest informal grinding tools in the Teotihuacan Valley (not fully formed metates as found during later time periods) demonstrating a group taking steps toward increased reliance on agricultural production. Finally, stable isotope analyses of human remains shows an increasing dependence on maize as a dietary staple.

While only four human burials were recovered, they revealed new details about health and migration, and provide an important glimpse into social relations. The individuals all had signs of nutritional stress and disease. Each is unique for the site and the region and show a degree of social differentiation that Nichols and Stoner had not anticipated within a small 6-ha village. One burial in particular presents the earliest evidence of social violence in the Teotihuacan Valley.

Altica also demonstrated intensifying exchange networks that ultimately contributed to the emergence of early complex societies in the region. Nichols and Stoner and their collaborators applied a multi-technique approach to source ceramics and obsidian artifacts from Altica and other key Early and Middle Formative sites in the Central Mexico macroregion. In total, 1,832 obsidian artifacts and 1,234 ceramic specimens were chemically sourced. They found that Altica imported a significant proportion of their decorated pottery from outside the Basin of Mexico, and some from other parts within the Basin. Most obsidian came from the nearby Otumba source, but Altica villagers imported small amounts from other sources too. Altica also may have played an important role in the early trade of Otumba obsidian. Intensification and expansion of these early trade networks formed the social and economic foundation that propelled subsequent Basin polities to prominence in Mesoamerica.

The broader impact of this project is to reinvigorate research on the Formative period in the Basin of Mexico that spanned the founding of the first villages to the development of the first cities and states. Importantly, Nichols and Stoner’s research shows how archaeology can discover important new details and understandings about the past from even small, disturbed early village sites. This project has taken significant steps to address the near lack of problem-oriented research at Formative sites in the Basin of Mexico over the past quarter century. The chemical sourcing studies have created composition databases for the Formative period in Central Mexico that other researchers can build upon. The project provided substantial training and research opportunities for younger archaeologists and students, predominately from under-represented groups in the U.S., in accordance with NSF priorities. The project also involved substantial collaboration among archaeologists, students, and organizations from both Mexico and the U.S. and thus has contributed to international scientific cooperation.
